comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Does anyone know where this baths was?  (Or these baths were?!)   I cannot find any reference to indoor baths in Sydney,  except for at Dawes Point.   Ironwork looks c.1890,  but there are electric lamps, so possibly later?

See Newcastle Municipal Baths -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/3377736316/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/3377736512/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I had to put this one in the too hard basket....until just now!...Whilst trawling thru the Sydney Mail, by pure fluke (!) I stumbled across a reference to a swimming carnival held at the Natatorium in Pitt St...hitherto I didn't know there was such a thing!...I'm not 100% sure, but I think this might be it! - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=175002 ...maybe there are better pics of the Natatorium around the place...if you think the SRNSW pic is of the Natatorium you might like to put the thumbnail up...I'm still trying to work out how to use my new toaster... Regardless of whether this is the Natatorium, this article on women's swimming in 19th and early 20th century Sydney is interesting...it mentions the Natatorium - www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/ASSHSSH/ASSHSSH09.pdf T&CJ description - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71236344 What became of the Natatorium - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71323342 The Natatorium must have been a hive of activity during its relatively brief lifetime...pages and pages of news items involving swimming club meetings come up on a digitised newspaper search...including this one! - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5250431

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Bravo!  Well found!  Pitt St Natatorium and People's Palace it is.  

I wonder why the photo ended up in State Records?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Happy to show you how to use your toaster (I taught [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] how to use his). In the meantime, here's the thumbnail link ... Interior of Natatorium, Pitt Street [SLNSW: Government Printing Office 1 - 09225] Great sleuthing. Hurrah (again) for the Sydney Mail!

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
"...By the early 1880s, besides the Woolloomooloo Bay
establishments, there were fenced-in enclosures on Sydney’s harbours
and rivers at Watson’s Bay, Lavender Bay, Balmain and Parramatta.
There was also a pile baths constructed at Lavender Bay, and sea baths
in existence at Coogee and Bronte. In 1883 the Balmain council
constructed a 30-yard tidal pool at “White Horse Point”. 

1886 saw a bathing complex opened at Lady Robinson’s Beach in the St George
area, and in 1888 Sydney’s first non-tidal pool, the Natatorium in Pitt
Street, was constructed by the Sydney Municipal Authority. 

The Natatorium, tilled with salt water pumped up from the Harbour almost
two miles away, would later become the administrative centre for
Sydney’s swimming fraternity. By 1900, most harbour and coastal
suburbs had their own pools - indicative of the boom swimming was
enjoying in the conducive social and physical climate of late 19th century
Australia..." (extract Australian Society for Sports History Incorporated)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: John Rae might be the connection - " ... Active in retirement, he owned the Peoples Palace and a natatorium and was a director of the Australian Gaslight Co. ... "
